Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 10/26/23 Staff 1 caught Youth H and Youth M in the bathroom
stall together in the school on Vista Maria's campus.
Investigation I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
I notified Complainant also School Staff 1 of this investigation
assignment. She expressed no additional concerns.
I notified Youth H’s Foster Care Worker that I was assigned to
investigate the allegation. She indicated a separation plan has
been in place for the two youth since Spring 2023. Youth H’s
Foster Care Worker did not have a copy of the plan.
I notified Youth M’s Foster Care Worker that I was assigned to
investigate the allegation. He expressed no additional concerns.
I contacted Therapist and requested a copy of the plan to
separate Youth H and Youth M. Therapist provided two written
plans dated 6/22/23; one for each youth entitled Special Plan for
Inappropriate Contact/Boundaries. Each plan only named one
youth and referred to the other as “Specified Youth.” Besides not
identifying both youths on a single plan, the plans were
complicated and detailed down to the amount of space that should
come between the youths. Item 1 of 8 indicated “Youth H and
Specified Youth will be placed on a 6-foot status from each other
ensuring safety for both until further notice. This includes school
hours.”
Therapist indicated that written separation plans are kept in a log
on the residential units for building staff to review. She said the
reason they do not include the names of both youths involved is
“so when they are distributed to each resident’s workers, we are
not breaching confidentiality.”
CCI licensing Rule 400.4130 Privacy and Confidentiality
indicates a resident’s identity may only be disclosed for public
purposes if certain criteria are met. The rule does not prohibit
sharing youth names among facility staff, privately contracted and
governmental child welfare placing agency staff (foster care,
adoption, juvenile justice, CPS/MIC), DCWL, courts, or
MISACWIS.
I interviewed School Staff 3 who has worked at Vista Maria for
nine years. He said according to the School Principal, “We don’t
2

abide by separation plans.” Further he said written plans are not
kept in the school and school staff are not aware of youths who
may require separation.
I met with School Principal for Clara B. Ford; the private charter
school located on Vista Maria’s campus. He said that separation
plans are not in effect and logistically cannot be abided by in the
school.
VIDEO
I reviewed video of the school hallway the morning of 10/26/23
showing Youth M and H in the bathroom together unsupervised
for approximately 7 minutes.
• 9:27:18 School Staff 2 is stationed at the far end of the hallway
near the exit door. Youth M leaves her classroom and enters the
bathroom.
• 9:28 Youth H is seen around the corner from the bathroom
talking to School Staff 1
• 9:28:20 Youth H enters Youth M’s classroom which is not
assigned to her.
• 9:28:55 Youth H leaves Youth M’s classroom, enters a different
classroom and exits.
• 9:29:06 Youth H enters the bathroom where Youth M has been
for two minutes.
• 9:37:30 School Staff 1 walks up and down the hall, then enters
the bathroom.
I interviewed Youth M, age 15, with Rights Officer present. She
has been at the facility for ten months and resides in Myriam Hall.
She said she and Youth H met at Clara B Ford School and are
“friends.” The two also see each other at “events” and group
therapy. On 10/26/23 Youth M said she was in the bathroom
when Youth H came in. She denied the two planned to meet
there at 9:30am. “I was in a stall. She slid under the door…I don’t
want to talk about it.” I asked if School Staff 1 caught them in one
stall together. Youth M said School Staff 1 entered the bathroom
and told them they were “both in trouble.” “I’m getting punished
and didn’t do anything,” she complained. I asked how she is
being punished and Youth M refused to discuss the matter further.
Youth H stated preferring they/them pronouns. I interviewed
them, age 16, with Rights Officer present. They said they have
been at Vista Maria for 18 months and reside in Freedom Hall.
3

Youth H said they attend school, groups and have the same lunch
period as Youth M. “I knew she (Youth M) was in the bathroom
because we planned to meet at 9:30am. We kissed inside the
stall.” Youth H said the kissing was consensual. I asked why they
slid underneath the stall. They said they locked the stall next to
Youth M then climbed into hers so they would appear to be in
separate stalls to reduce the likelihood of getting caught by staff.
Youth H referred to Youth M with she/her pronouns during the first
portion of the interview. Midway through, they informed me Youth
M also prefers they/them pronouns and began referring to Youth
M as they/them. “They’re my girlfriend. We’ve been dating for
eight months as of Wednesday and it’s our anniversary,” they
offered excitedly.
I asked Youth H what happened when School Staff 1 caught them
in the bathroom. They said School Staff 1 saw them through the
crack in the door, wrote an incident report and the youths received
consequences. “We were not allowed to attend the Homecoming
Dance and Youth M can’t go to Trunk or Treat.”
I interviewed Complainant/School Staff 1 who has worked at
Vista Maria for five years. She said School Staff 2 was monitoring
the far end of the hallway and she and at least three other school
staff were monitoring the exit doors and other hallways. “I went
into the bathroom because I noticed Youth H was gone too long.
Both of the two stalls were locked. Through the crack, I saw them
jump away from each other.” I asked if Youth H and M are on a
special separation plan and she said, “No.”
I interviewed School Staff 2 who has worked at Vista Maria for
five months. She said she was at the far end of the hall and did
not see Youth M or Youth H enter the bathroom. There are two
stalls, but when two are inside, a staff person is supposed to stand
in the doorway. I asked if Youth H and M are on a special
separation plan. She said separation plans are not applicable at
school.
I interviewed School Supervisor who has worked at Vista Maria
for 22 years. She said there are usually six school staff assigned
to monitor the halls and exit doors. “Whoever is in the hall
watches the bathroom. No particular staff is assigned to monitor
the bathroom. We have no knowledge of documented safety or
separation plans. If we had a simple, uncomplicated plan to keep
two youths separate, it still wouldn’t be 100% foolproof.”
4

I attempted to interview Vista Maria’s Vice President of
Academic Programming. However, she resigned six weeks ago
and could not be interviewed.
I reviewed Vista Maria’s Guidelines for Staff called Back to Basics.
It indicates that school staff supervise clients while they are in the
bathroom. Rights Officer clarified that this applies if more than
one youth is in the school bathroom.
Analysis School staff did not follow Vista Maria’s Guidelines that requires
them to supervise more than one youth in the school bathroom.
School staff must abide by separation plans that indicate youths
will be separated at school.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
It is not only acceptable, its essential to identify both youths on
written separation plans. Separation and other special behavior
plans should be available to staff who work in the school.
As stated above, Rule 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality
does not prohibit sharing youth names among facility staff,
privately contracted and governmental child welfare placing
agency staff (foster care, adoption, juvenile justice, CPS/MIC),
DCWL staff, courts, and MISACWIS. Youth identities must be
shared as it is required for facility and child welfare staff to perform
their jobs.
Additionally, Vista Maria has provided redacted incident reports
and other documents missing the names of youths to DCWL
Consultants during the course of special investigations and should
not be.
See Public Act 116 – MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and
examination of conditions, books, records, and reports; access by
department (defined as MDHHS on page 2), bureau of fire
services, or local authorities; records; report; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of confidential records; child
information cards to be provided to department; failure of licensee
to cooperate with investigation, inspection, or examination
indicates:
(1) The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may investigate and
examine the books and records of the licensee. The licensee shall
cooperate with the department’s investigation, inspection, and
5

examination by doing all of the following: (a) Admitting members
of the department into the childcare organization and furnishing all
reasonable facilities for thorough examination of its books,
records, and reports. (b) Allowing the department to perform
routine investigative functions during the course of an
investigation, inspection, or examination. Routine investigative
functions include, but are not limited to, interviewing potential
witnesses, such as staff and household members, and taking
photographs to assess and document the conditions of the
childcare organization and its compliance with this act and the
rules promulgated under this act. (c) Providing accurate and
truthful information to the department, and encouraging witnesses,
such as staff and household members, to provide accurate and
truthful information to the department…(3) A licensee shall keep
the records the department prescribes regarding each child in its
control and care and shall report to the department, when
requested, the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department. Except as
otherwise provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and their
parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure of this
information shall be properly safeguarded by the childcare
organization, the department, and any other entity in possession
of the information. Records that are confidential under this section
are available to both of the following: (a) A standing or select
committee or appropriations subcommittee of either house of the
legislature having jurisdiction over protective services matters for
children, according to section 7 of the child protection law, 1975
PA 238, MCL 722.627. (b) The children’s ombudsman established
in section 3 of the children’s ombudsman act, 1994 PA 204, MCL
722.923. 51 (4) Notwithstanding subsection (3) and sections 5 and
7(2) of the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.625 and
722.627, information or records in the possession of the
department or the department of licensing and regulatory affairs
may be shared to the extent necessary for the proper functioning
of the department or the department of licensing and regulatory
affairs in administering child welfare or child care licensing under
this act or in an investigation conducted under section 43b of the
social welfare act, 1939 PA 280, MCL 400.43b. Information or
records shared under this subsection shall not be released by the
department or the department of licensing and regulatory affairs
unless otherwise permitted under this act or other state or federal
law. Neither the department nor the department of licensing and
regulatory affairs shall release or open for inspection any
document, report, or record authored by or obtained from another
6

agency or organization unless 1 of the conditions of section 7(10)
of the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.627, applies.
CONSULTATION
Therapist wrote separation plans indicating youth should be
separated at school. However, school staff indicated they did not
see the plans or abide by them in school. Before writing plans to
be implemented by other staff, therapists should first check with
Unit Managers, Residential Supervisors, School Supervisor, and
anyone else involved to make sure staff are able to follow the
plan. Plans should be distributed to all staff, including school staff,
and written in a way that is realistic and easy to understand.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2023C0000510, intake 6/1/23, CAP approved 7/25/23
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and a corrective action plan is required.
